message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy of reduction for the following reaction: 
Fe2O3 (s) + 3 H2(g) → 2 Fe(s) + 3 H2O(g)
Given: 
ΔH°f for Fe2O3 (s) = -824.2 kJ/mol 
ΔH°f for H2O(g) = -241.8 kJ/mol
ΔH°f for Fe(s) = 0 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy of reduction for the given reaction, we can use the following formula:

ΔH°rxn = Σ ΔH°f(products) - Σ ΔH°f(reactants)

For the products, we have 2 moles of Fe(s) and 3 moles of H2O(g). For the reactants, we have 1 mole of Fe2O3(s) and 3 moles of H2(g). The ΔH°f for H2(g) is 0 kJ/mol since it is in its standard state.

ΔH°rxn = [(2 mol Fe × ΔH°f(Fe)) + (3 mol H2O × ΔH°f(H2O))] - [(1 mol Fe2O3 × ΔH°f(Fe2O3)) + (3 mol H2 × ΔH°f(H2))]

ΔH°rxn = [(2 mol × 0 kJ/mol) + (3 mol × -241.8 kJ/mol)] - [(1 mol × -824.2 kJ/mol) + (3 mol × 0 kJ/mol)]

ΔH°rxn = [0 kJ + (-725.4 kJ)] - [-824.2 kJ]

ΔH°rxn = -725.4 kJ + 824.2 kJ

ΔH°rxn = 98.8 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy of reduction for the given reaction is 98.8 kJ/mol.
